title: What is the meaning of core i3, i5 and i7, in terms I can an understand? - Quora

response.answer_text: For the sake of simplicity, I will describe the Intel lineup of processors. “Cores” are basically processors that can work together to accomplish more, faster. “Threads” are how many cores the processor thinks that it has. Telling the processor to think that it has more cores than it actually does can make it faster in some cases. Celeron processors are commonly found in Chromebooks, and low-end computers to reduce the cost of manufacture. 10 and 11 inch laptops normally have these processors, and they are normally for web browsing, and basic word processing. They commonly have 2 cores and 2 threads. Pentium processors are commonly found in Windows laptops, independent in size. They are again great for web browsing and word processing tasks, and are also low-cost. They have 2 cores and 2 threads. Core i3 processors are found in low to mid cost laptops, and are good for somewhat more advanced tasks, such as making spreadsheets, slideshows, and advanced word processing. They have 2 cores and 4 threads. Core i5 processors are good for lots of tasks at a time, and they can be used for mid-range gaming, when paired with a system that is graphically capable of gaming. These are found in mid to high priced systems. They are commonly found in offices, for lots of productivity tasks. They commonly have 4 cores and 4 threads, but in some laptops, they have 2 cores and 2 threads. Core i7 processors are meant for a heavy workload, or heavy gaming. On a desktop, they have 4 or 8 cores, 4, 8, or 16 threads, but in a laptop, they can have 2 or 4 cores, and 4 threads usually. Intel Xeon processors are mostly used in servers and they have an insane amount of cores, like 16 or something. They are designed for servers, and are very rarely in laptops. They can also be put into 3D modelling computers, but rarely, people have these in their home. If this helps you, I am writing this on an Intel Core i3 laptop, that I mostly use for MS Office, and web browsing at school. It performs well for these tasks.

In the simplest terms, i3, i5 and i7 are three grades of computer processors, the lowest being of the three being i3 and the highest being i7. (there are actually a lot more processor grades, but the question was asked for only these three, and these three are the most well known.) Now comes the actual features that set the three apart from each other. I will start with the i7 because it makes the i5 and i3 easier to explain. The i7 generally is faster clockspeed (has more GHz, making it faster) and generally has more cores than the i5 and i3 (more cores = better multitasking and processing power). It also has two features that sets it apart from the two lower end processors: hyper-threading and turbo boost. Hyper-threading allows the processor to turn each of it’s physical cores into two virtual cores called threads. Turbo boosting allows the processor to push past it’s base clockspeed depending on how much processing power is required. For example, if the base clockspeed is 4.0 GHz, and your running a very intense game, turbo boosting would push the clockspeed to 4.5 GHz. these are the two major features that i7 has over the i5 and i3, but better processor = big price tag.i5 generally has slightly lower clockspeed than an i7, but more than an i3, and it generally has more cores than an i3, but less than an i7. The i5 has turbo boosting enabled, but it does not have hyper threading enabled. Middle to high price tag, but my personal opinion is that the i5 line has the best output for price, if you find a good i5 processor.i3 generally has the lowest clockspeed of the three, and the least amount of cores. It has hyper-threading eneabled, but no turbo boosting. Unless you are on a very tight budget, or onl6 use a computer for web surfing, an i3 is something you should stay away from. This is simply my opinion though.Keep in mind that I said “generally” when talking about clockspeed and cores, because the lines can be blurred when saying “an i7 has faster clockspeed than an i5!” An i7 with 8 cores will almost surely have lower clockspeed than an i5 with 4 cores, but the i7 will be more powerful than the i5 due to the larger amount of cores. Although there is more nitty gritty stuff to say about processors, this is a basic rundown of i3, i5 and i7. Hope this helps!!

Hi Stranger! The Core i3, Core i5, and Core i7 are models of Intel processors. When you see a sticker on the front of a PC case showing one of those it gives you a general idea of what to expect from the CPU’s performance. The Intel Core i3 processor family are CPUs focused at the value-end of the performance spectrum. These are CPUs that are lower cost and are lower performing. Good for browsing the web, and doing basic computer tasks, but not great for medium and heavy workloads, etc. The Intel Core i5 processor family are CPUs targeted at the mid-range performance/price point. These processors are great for general PC use and will do basically everything you need a PC to do. And that leaves us with the Core i7 CPUs. Intel considers these chips to be the higher-end of the range. The only CPUs higher are the Core i9 CPUs, which are very expensive compared to their lower-numbered family members. Keep in mind that the i3,5,7,9 designations are used with all the modern generations of Intel CPUs. Recently Intel announced the 10th generation of processors, all with the same Core i3,5,9 designation but specific model numbers behind them. E.g. Core i9-10900K, etc. In the end, the numbers really give you an ‘at-a-glance’ understanding of the performance you’ll get if you were to buy that processor. Can i3 chips play games? Sure! There’s more to what makes a great PC than just it’s CPU, but having an understanding of it’s processing power will tell you a lot about what the system’s overall capability and performance is. ~Rich If you appreciated my answer and it was helpful, consider upvoting it!

The i3-i5-i7 indicates the tiers between processors of the same category. You can usually divide them into three use cases: i3: entry level user. If you only need Word, Excell, YouTube or other light entertainment, this is all you need. Great for grandparents, for younger kids to do their homework, … .i5: regular user. If you use your pc every day, you’ll benefit from an i5 over an i3. So everyone who uses their pc professionally, or to play games or do some photoshopping in your spare time, this is the one for you.i7: professional. If you need an i7, you probably know it. Usually the i7 is fairly similar to the i5, and only specialized software benefits from its advanced features. Multimedia editing and engineering applications are the most common use cases.Be aware of the fact that this only holds within the same category: laptop processors are usually a lot weaker than desktops for example.

The core i3 is more of a budget friendly CPU from that generation, with 2 cores (except in the newest generation they have 4). These CPUs are great for light gaming in 1080p, or other small tasks that doesn't require more cores or threads. the core i5 is a mid range CPU with 4 cores and 6 in the newest generation. These CPUs are great for mid-high end PCs and are good for gaming up to 1440p when paired with a good graphics card. The core i7 is the CPU for high end PCs and usually have 4 core and 8 threads, although in the newest generation it has 6 cores and 12 threads making them better against the core i5 and i3 in things like video editing, or things that are heavy on the CPU. Generally the same thing will apply for the AMD Ryzen CPUs like the Ryzen 3, Ryzen 5 Ryzen 7 and there very high end Ryzen threadripper.

Celeron - lowest end possible. Think Chrome book or a repair shops “loaner” Pentium - entry level Think cheap commuter car i3 - Advanced entry level Think Nice Commuter Car i5- regular user Think Average Sedan/Minivan i7- Workstation user CAD/Video Editing/ Enthusist Gamer Think: Race Car/Semi Truck i9- Highest end workstations, Monster Gaming machines. Think Formula 1/NASCAR - to Train.

It has nothing to do with cores. It’s just a classification of processors. i3<i5<17< and soon I think i9. The higher the number the more more it is capable of. Exp. the i3 procesors don’t have turbo boost (overclocking) most of the i5 have. And so the i7 have something the i5 don’t have. And so on. When looking for processor or any other computer thing. First determine you price range. Then look for the best in that price range. In processors look for bigger cache then, the number of cores and then the speed. If you are buying i5 or i7 better go for something with 4 cores than more speed. And lower the architecture displayed in nano meters, the less power it needs. (important for laptops)

The Mazda CX3 is smaller and less powerful than the Mazda CX5, which is smaller and less powerful than the Mazda CX7. All three will seat 5 adults. But the higher models will do so more comfortably and with less noticeable performance and handling changes. The core i3 is smaller and less powerful than the core i5, which is smaller and less powerful than the core i7. All three will run Windows. But the higher models will do so more comfortably and with less noticeable performance and response time changes.

The I7 has passed al quality control tests for that designation, The I5 has failed the quality tests for I7 but can be configuerd for the standards determined for I5 same chip batch as before. The I3 has failed the I5 quality test but can be configured to meet I3 standards, and again this chip came from the same batch as the I7 chip. There are also server chips taken from this batch as well as specialpupose chips that may be single use chips that have failed some key tests or even chips singled out because they fail zero tests.

No need to be fancy about it: they correspond roughly to entry-level, mainstream and high-end desktops. Entry-level here means mostly browsing, perhaps with some movie-watching. Mainstream adds occasional use of tools like Excel. High-end means sustained, professional, intense use of applications that might also include larger documents, page-layout, perhaps basic engineering-type number crunching (simulations, etc).

Ryzen (AMD) numbers their processors the same way.
